The study mainly used numbers and statistics, collecting data from 1,458 students involved in student clubs out of 1,608 questionnaires sent out. This data was analyzed using methods like descriptive analysis, correlation analysis, and structural equation modeling to understand how the different factors are related. The study found that the key factors influencing student clubs' switching intentions include perceived boredom, perceived dissatisfaction, perceived usefulness, experiential motivation, and switching cost. Experts finally developed and validated the REES strategy, confirming its effectiveness in reducing student club switch intention. Boredom is an emotional perception. Understanding what perceived boredom means is complicated and requires looking at different theories, including psychodynamic, existential, arousal, and cognitive theories (Bench & Lench, 2013; Raffaelli et al., 2018). When people are not successful in focusing their attention on activities that are aligned with their desired goals, the psycho-emotional indicator at that point is defined as perceived boredom (Westgate & Wilson, 2018). Although there are various definitions of perceived boredom, researchers agree that perceived boredom is a transient, unpleasant emotional experience that indicates an individual’s failure to engage in a desirable situation; the individual wants to get rid of this perception, and a range of behavioral and social outcomes accompany it. In the life of college student organizations, students may also attempt to seek alternative organizations for obtaining pleasurable stimulation when the pleasure benefits of the original organization are reduced (Line et al., 2016). Thus, perceived boredom often triggers substitution of existing clubs, as well as boredom with existing clubs as an emotional cause of psychological ageing, and when students perceive disinterest, it usually leads to switching to existing clubs or club activities. Dissatisfaction, the opposite of satisfaction, should better reflect the psychology of users who don't use it often. Anderson & Sullivan (1993) defined satisfaction as the positive evaluation and positive emotions of a user after using a particular product or service, while the negative evaluation or negative emotions about this product were defined as dissatisfaction. In contrast to the focus on satisfaction and continued use in technology acceptance studies, dissatisfaction is often the first step in a user’s willingness to transfer. Some studies have indicated that dissatisfaction has an impact on user transfer when users realize the attractiveness of alternatives. Huang & Yan (2019) showed in his research that satisfaction is an evaluation of the subjective feelings a user acquires after experiencing a specific product or service, typically based on certain standards or expectations regarding the quality, functionality, price, and other evaluative aspects. In this research, perceived fun dissatisfaction refers to students’ overall emotional feelings, evaluations, and inner experience of their student organization. It is influenced not only by the subjective factors of students’ individual professional backgrounds and learning goals, but also by the objective factors of interpersonal relations and knowledge supply, which contribute to an overall emotional perspective. If the user experience provided by the original student organization does not meet their expectations, students may become dissatisfied and choose to join other organizations. The positive and significant impact of dissatisfaction on conversion intention has been confirmed by research on user transfer behavior. Dissatisfaction is usually the beginning of students’ transfer behavior, and it is the main thrust factor affecting their conversion intention. Perceived usefulness generally refers to the extent to which external factors affect individuals’ perceptions and attitudes towards things, which in turn affects their switch intention. It can be seen that perceived usefulness will lead to intrinsic motivation, the stronger the perceived usefulness of a thing or behavior, the more likely the individual will adopt the behavior or take positive action to achieve the goal. At the same time, perceived usefulness is one of the most important pull factors in the PPM model. Perceived usefulness is an important concept in the theory of technology acceptance model and is a determinant of an individual’s use of a system, specifically the extent to which an individual believes that the use of a system or technology will increase his or her learning and job performance, that is, the extent to which he or she believes that the use of the system or technology will improve his or her learning and work performance. “Perceived usefulness” can be defined as the consumer’s belief that using water bottles made of recyclable plastic will be good for the environment. The higher the consumer’s perceived usefulness of an environmentally friendly product, the higher his or her purchase intention for that product. Perceived usefulness is “the extent to which a person believes that using a particular system will improve his or her job performance”. Perceived usefulness explains the users’ perception that the interactive mobile map innovation will improve their task performance in terms of ease of location finding. Users can see the value of the innovation in performing their tasks and the extent to which mobile maps are useful in reducing the time it takes to get where they are going, where they are or the distance from one location to another.

Experiential motivation can also stimulate people’s mental and physical activities, making them move toward their goals. It is an important part of human behavior and psychological state (Dann, 1981). Xi (1997) pointed out in his work that motivation is a psychological process and a subjective factor that usually inspires the generation and maintenance of individual behaviors through personal interests, ideals, or desires. Several scholars study the consumption habits of customers in the tourism industry and find a correlation between their internal needs and their travel behavior. Gan (2011) showed that travel demands experiential motivation referring to the motivation to promote people to produce travel behaviors and make them in a positive state to achieve certain goals. Experiential motivation frequently manifests as desires, intentions, thoughts, beliefs, and so on. Need refers to the “desire” and “demand” for tangible things based on specific living conditions; tourism demand arises from travel experiential motivation as well as the interplay between tourism demand and experiential motivation. The internal driving force of promoting tourists to carry out tourism activities comes from the experiential motivation stimulated by tourism demand. Experiential motivation is the most critical factor for understanding tourist behavior and is widely used in research related to leisure vacations, decision-making, market segmentation, destination development, and post-disaster reconstruction. Experiential motivation is highly significant in the study of human and animal behavior. Bao (2005) and others pointed out that motivation refers to the initiation, continuation, or termination of a behavior by humans or animals at a specific time. The motivational state is typically understood as an internal force that creates a tendency to engage in goal-oriented behavior, and there exists competition among different motivational states, with the winner of this competition playing a decisive role. Switching cost, which originated from economic studies earlier, refers to the one-time cost that customers need to pay when switching between consumer goods or service providers (Burnham.et al., 2003). However, with the continuous expansion of customer satisfaction analysis, the concept of switching costs has gradually entered many fields such as management. In the research of user loyalty, Dick & Basu (1994) proposed that switching cost refer to the cost incurred by customers during the switching process, including time cost, money cost and psychological cost. It is mainly defined as the potential risks or possible losses perceived by customers when switching operators, such as financial losses, performance losses, social losses, psychological losses, safety losses, etc. Kim et al. (2019) believe that cost refers to the difficulties that customers who are dissatisfied with the existing services may encounter when switching to another supplier, which is mainly manifested in the economic, social and psychological burdens felt by customers when switching to a new supplier. Hsieh et al. (2012) believed that switching costs refer to the time and energy spent by users of blogs when transitioning to social networking service (SNS) platforms. Conversion intention, a crucial concept in behavioral research, serves as a tool to comprehend and forecast individuals' conversion behavior in various scenarios. It refers to the tendency of an individual to change the current choice in a given situation due to dissatisfaction with the existing service, product, organization, etc., or increased attraction to alternative options. The concept was initially mainly used in marketing and consumer behavior research, and then expanded to other fields, such as education, health services, information technology, etc. Experts and scholars from various fields-initiated research and expansion at different levels. The willingness to switch refers to the tendency of individuals to decide to change service providers due to dissatisfaction with current services or attractiveness to alternative services (Bansal et al., 2005). Many factors, including satisfaction, conversion cost, attractiveness of alternative options, and social influence, influence the multi-dimensional concept of switching intention. This research was conducted at Zhengzhou Technology Business University (ZTBU), and its main target is students who participate in student clubs, including ordinary members and student leaders. The research employs a convenient sampling method. Based on the sample size student samples were selected from each selected school, ensuring that a sufficient number of samples were obtained from different schools and student clubs, the student population of ZTBU was 2966. Then, the total sample of students from the student clubs of 8 schools in ZTBU are selected in this study was 1458. The researcher began distributing the questionnaires from August to September 2024. All collected questionnaire data were meticulously revised, exported, and verified, and then imported into Smart PLS and SPSS for data analysis and processing.

There are two parts to the questionnaire. The first part mainly asks for background information from the respondents, such as gender, grade, position, school, and learning level, to facilitate systematic analysis. The second part consists of the items for each variable. On the basis of consulting a large number of literatures, the item of each variable is determined, and the item of each variable is from the authoritative literature. After front-and- expert verification, any semantic or phrasing in the questionnaire that may cause confusion or misunderstanding is corrected, making the presentation of the questionnaire items more accurate and easier to understand. At this point, the preliminary research questionnaire design of this study was completed, and the main questionnaire included 30 items: perceived boredom (PB) had 6 items, perceived dissatisfaction (PD) had 4 items, perceived usefulness (PU) had 4 items, experiential motivation (EM) had 5 items, switching cost (SC) had 7 items, and student clubs switching intention (SOSI) had 4 items. The perceived attitudes of all students toward each factor were measured using a 5-point Likert scale, and respondents were asked to rate the degree to which they agreed to be asked about the item. Each question is rated from “strongly disagree” to “agree” on a scale of 1 to 5, where 1 means “strongly disagree”, 2 means “relatively disagree”, 3 means “general”, 4 means “relatively agree”, and 5 means “strongly agree”. A total of 40 questionnaires were collected in the pilot test, and the analysis shows that Cronbach’s alpha is 0.907, with each part scoring above 0.7, which means the questionnaires are reliable and meet the standards. The KMO values for the variables are all above 0.7, showing that the data is very suitable for factor analysis, and the questions in the questionnaire have good structural validity, making the data analysis more effective. The KMO values for all variables exceed 0.7, indicating that the variable scale data are highly suitable for factor analysis. Additionally, the design questions of the questionnaire demonstrate relatively good structural validity, making the data analysis of the questionnaire results more effective. The above correlation analysis supports all the proposed hypotheses. The positive correlations between the variables indicate that the more pronounced the students’ perceived boredom and perceived dissatisfaction with the current organization, the stronger the students’ willingness to switch; and the more the students’ perceived usefulness and pleasure and sense of belonging to the new organization, the stronger the students’ desire to switch. Negative correlations between variables indicate that assessment costs, learning costs, and emotional costs significantly inhibit students’ willingness to switch. This study explored the significant effects of perceived boredom, perceived dissatisfaction, perceived usefulness, experiential motivation, and switching costs on student clubs' switching intentions using structural equation modeling (SEM). The results of path analysis and significance test indicated that perceived boredom, perceived dissatisfaction, perceived usefulness, experiential motivation and switching cost can directly affect student clubs switching intentions. The results of this study are consistent in most aspects with the relevant theories and previous findings, indicating that perceived boredom, perceived dissatisfaction, perceived usefulness, experiential motivation and switching cost have significant effects on student clubs switching intentions. However, there are some differences, which may be related to factors such as school support, regional differences, individual student differences, and the effectiveness of specific measures. Perceived boredom directly affects willingness to switch, supporting related studies by Maier et al. (2021) and Markey et al. (2014). However, schools with greater support in terms of financial investment, venue facilities, and instructor staffing will effectively reduce student clubs’ switching intentions through colorful reunion activities. Perceived dissatisfaction directly affects switching intentions, which is consistent with Cheng et al. (2019). Perceived usefulness directly affects switching intention, supporting the findings of Hsieh et al. (2012). However, the degree of perceived usefulness is a judgment based on a comparison between the current organization and the new organization. If the current organization meets students’ needs for professional development and networking resources, it reduces their perceived usefulness of the new organization; therefore, the current organization can address this issue by enhancing its organizational attractiveness.

Creating a distinctive organizational culture and a sound incentive mechanism can effectively stimulate students’ experiential motivation, which in turn reduces their willingness to switch. Switching cost directly affects switching intention, which is consistent with the findings of numerous previous studies. As student satisfaction in the current organization increases, so does the switching cost, which in turn reduces switching intention; therefore, enhancing both the attractiveness and satisfaction of the current organization can effectively discourage students from switching. The detailed analyses above clearly demonstrate how each variable affects student clubs’ switching intentions and how these effects align with relevant theories and research findings. Based on the results of these analyses, schools can take targeted measures, such as enriching activity carriers, strengthening knowledge empowerment, building a distinctive culture, reinforcing school support, and improving incentive mechanisms, to reduce student clubs’ switching intentions. To propose and implement strategies to reduce student clubs’ switching intentions, the researcher developed the REES strategy based on the results of the quantitative analysis. The strategy includes: R: Reduce Perceived Boredom: designing diversified activity programs and increasing the frequency of activities to reduce students’ boredom. It is crucial to foster a warm and harmonious team atmosphere to facilitate adequate and effective communication among E: Enhancing Satisfaction: strengthen the effective linkage with internal and external resources to obtain more resource support and inject more vitality into the organization. Encourage students to give full play to their initiative to enhance their sense of participation and responsibility. E: Enhancing Organizational Attractiveness: empower students with the knowledge and skills they need to meet their practical requirements. Carry out leadership training and effectively organize activities to enhance the overall atmosphere of the organization. S: Stimulate Experiential Motivation: create a unique organizational culture to enhance students’ sense of belonging and pride and stimulate their motivation for participation and loyalty. Regularly recognize outstanding students and inspire them to look up to role models. The experts have confirmed that the REES strategy works, and its related part greatly lowers students' desire to switch, which agrees with a study by Hsieh et al. (2012) that shows how important it is for the organization to be useful in keeping students from switching.
